War & Law

International humanitarian law is a set of rules that seek to limit the effects of armed conflict. It protects people who are not or are no longer participating in hostilities and restricts the means and methods of warfare.

Geneva Conventions

Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/treaties-customary-law/geneva-conventions

Humanitarian Law & Policy blog

Link: http://blogs.icrc.org/law-and-policy/

Sources of international humanitarian law

IHL is based on a number of treaties, in particular the Geneva Conventions of 1949 and their Additional Protocols, and a series of other instruments.

Treaties, States Parties and Commentaries Link: https://ihl-databases.icrc.org/applic/ihl/ihl.nsf/vwTreatiesByTopics.xsp

Customary international law consists of rules that come from "a general practice accepted as law" and that exist independent of treaty law.

Customary IHL database Link: https://ihl-databases.icrc.org/customary-ihl/eng/docs/home?opendocument

Search Across all IHL Databases

Topics

Current debates on IHL

Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/contemporary-challenges-for-ihl

Understanding and responding to challenges to IHL brought on by contemporary conflicts.

Protected persons

Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/protected-persons

IHL protects a wide range of people during armed conflict. 

Civilians Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/protected-persons/civilians

Wounded, sick, and shipwrecked Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/protected-persons/wounded-sick-and-shipwrecked

Prisoners of war and detainees Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/protected-persons/prisoners-war-detainees

View all Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/protected-persons

Weapons

Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/weapons

IHL governs the choice of weapons and prohibits or restricts the use of certain weapons.

Explosive weapons in populated areas Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/explosive-weapons-populated-areas

Nuclear weapons Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/weapons/nuclear-weapons

Review of new weapons Link: https://www.icrc.org/eng/war-and-law/weapons/new-weapons/index.jsp

View all Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/weapons

Conduct of hostilities

Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/conduct-hostilities

IHL aims to strike a balance between legitimate military objectives and the humanitarian objective of reducing suffering, particularly among civilians.

Methods and means of warfare Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/conduct-hostilities/methods-means-warfare

Cyber warfare Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/conduct-hostilities/cyber-warfare

Cultural property Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/conduct-hostilities/cultural-property

View all Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/conduct-hostilities

Use of emblems

Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/emblem

The red cross, red crescent and red crystal emblems are a visible manifestation of the protection accorded to military medical services and relief workers in armed conflicts. 

Emblems of humanity Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/publication/0876-emblems-humanity

View all Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/emblem

Violations of IHL

Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/international-criminal-jurisdiction

When violations of IHL occur, States are under obligation to prosecute offenders. Domestic courts therefore play an important role in the enforcement of IHL. In addition to national jurisdictions, violations of IHL can also be prosecuted by various international criminal tribunals.

International Criminal Tribunals Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/international-criminal-jurisdiction

Domestic courts Link: https://www.icrc.org/eng/resources/documents/legal-fact-sheet/national-enforcement-ihl-information-kit.htm

Other mechanism Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/document/international-humanitarian-fact-finding-commission-facsheet

View all Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/international-criminal-jurisdiction

Domestic law and IHL

Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/ihl-domestic-law

For IHL treaties to be universally accepted, all States must adopt them and then enact legislation and take practical measures in order for the rules to be fully effective. The ICRC’s Advisory Service can help, by providing assistance and documentation.

ICRC national implementation database Link: https://www.icrc.org/ihl-nat

National Committees Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/ihl-domestic-law/national-committees

Documentation Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/ihl-domestic-law/documentation

View all Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/ihl-domestic-law

Bodies of law related to IHL

Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/ihl-other-legal-regimes

IHL and other legal regimes are complementary in armed conflicts.

Human rights Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/ihl-other-legal-regmies/ihl-human-rights

Refugee law Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/protected-persons/refugees-displaced-persons

Jus ad bellum Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/ihl-other-legal-regmies/jus-in-bello-jus-ad-bellum

View all Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/ihl-other-legal-regimes

Strengthening IHL project

Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/strengthening-ihl

For IHL to effectively regulate the behaviour of warring parties, there is a need for both adequate rules and actual respect for those rules.

Strengthening IHL protecting detainees Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/document/detention-non-international-armed-conflict-icrcs-work-strengthening-legal-protection-0

Strengthening compliance with IHL Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/document/strengthening-compliance-international-humanitarian-law-ihl-work-icrc-and-swiss-government (2012-2015)

View all Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/strengthening-ihl

Featured publications

Commentary on the First Geneva Convention Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/document/updated-commentaries-first-geneva-convention

The first in a series of updated Commentaries to the 1949 Geneva Conventions and their 1977 Additional Protocols, published online by the ICRC and in print by Cambridge University Press.

Commentary on the Second Geneva Convention Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/document/second-geneva-convention-and-role-icrc

Protection considerations in the law of naval warfare: The Second Geneva Convention and the role of the ICRC.

How does law protect in war? Link: https://www.icrc.org/casebook/

Cases, documents and teaching materials on contemporary practice in international humanitarian law.

International review of the Red Cross Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/international-review

A quarterly journal published by the ICRC and Cambridge University Press.

This e-briefing series presents a short introduction and overview on topics related to humanitarian law, policy and action.

View all publications Link: https://shop.icrc.org/publications/international-humanitarian-law.html

Library and research services Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/library-and-research-services

The library and Research Service offers over 140,000 documents on IHL and the ICRC's work

Services & resources

Legal advisory service

Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/document/icrc-advisory-services-international-humanitarian-law#.VL5C8yinG30

Promoting and implementing IHL is primarily the responsibility of States and the Advisory Service on IHL assist them to fulfil their obligations.

Teaching and learning IHL

Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/what-we-do/building-respect-ihl/education-outreach

The ICRC emphasize IHL teaching in secondary schools and universities, to reach tomorrow's decision-makers and opinion-leaders.

Law and policy platform

Link: https://www.icrc.org/en/war-and-law/law-and-policy

A wealth of resources connecting international humanitarian law with the policies that guide humanitarian action.
